br.eti.fml.machinegun
Class Army

java.lang.Object
  br.eti.fml.behavior.Factory<MachineGun>
      br.eti.fml.machinegun.Army

public class Army
extends Factory<MachineGun>

Produces machine guns. Also, organize the thread consumers to let the bullet (data) reach the specified target. Bullets are data, and bullets are from a specific type. A machine gun is a way to make this processing very fast, asynchronously.

Before to take a new machine gun, don't forget to start a mission.

Constructor Detail

Army

public Army(ArmyAudit armyAudit,
            PersistedQueueManager persistedQueueManager)
Create a new Army. See startANewMission(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, br.eti.fml.behavior.Factory>, br.eti.fml.machinegun.Capsule, int, int, int) to have some fun.

Parameters:
armyAudit - If you want to take control of your Army. See NegligentAuditor if you don't need of an auditorship. This parameter don't accept null.
persistedQueueManager - Specific queue implementation.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if some parameters are null.
Method Detail

startANewMission

public <T> void startANewMission(java.lang.String missionName,
                                 java.lang.String queueName,
                                 Factory<DirtyWork<T>> dirtyWorkFactory,
                                 Capsule<T> capsule,
                                 int volatileBufferSize,
                                 int numberOfBufferConsumers,
                                 int numberOfPersistedQueueConsumers)
This function will create and start a mission asynchronously. This associates a Mission with a dirty work factory. You have to use different queues to each kind of work; in other words: each queue will transport only ONE kind of data.

Parameters:
missionName - An arbitrary mission name. Can be the same of queueName.
queueName - The queue name where the "bullets" (data) from the machine guns will be transported to the final target. If you are using a JMS based queue, it is the javax.jms.Queue#getQueueName(). Remember that this name is not an arbitrary name, you have to configure it in some place of your PersistedQueueManager specific implementation.
dirtyWorkFactory - the associated factory of dirty works. When the "bullet" (data) reaches the target, the dirty work will be executed using the data as parameter.
capsule - A Capsule is a way to keep the "bullet" (data) intact through the way to the target. It have to be able to convert a data to a byte array and vice-versa. If you are really lazy use GenericCapsuleForLazyPeople.
volatileBufferSize - It is the internal buffer size. If the buffer is full, the MachineGun.fire(T) function will be blocked until the consumers could drain the volume. You can use Mission.DEFAULT_VOLATILE_BUFFER_SIZE. Set high values if you have high available memory and don't care so much about lost some data. Remember that what is on the buffer will not be persisted. If is important to persist EVERYTHING, set this parameter to 1.
numberOfBufferConsumers - The number of thread consumers to read from internal buffer and put on the persisted queue. Use Mission.SMART_NUMBER_OF_CONSUMERS to make the function calculates based on your available processors.
numberOfPersistedQueueConsumers - The number of embedded queue thread consumers. This consumers will do the dirty and hard work. Use Mission.SMART_NUMBER_OF_CONSUMERS to make the function calculates based on your available processors.

startANewMission

public <T> void startANewMission(java.lang.String missionName,
                                 java.lang.String queueName,
                                 Factory<DirtyWork<T>> dirtyWorkFactory,
                                 Capsule<T> capsule)
Call startANewMission(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, br.eti.fml.behavior.Factory>, br.eti.fml.machinegun.Capsule, int, int, int) using default values to volatileBufferSize, numberOfBufferConsumers and numberOfPersistedQueueConsumers.

Parameters:
missionName - see startANewMission(String, String, br.eti.fml.behavior.Factory, Capsule, int, int, int)
queueName - see startANewMission(String, String, br.eti.fml.behavior.Factory, Capsule, int, int, int)
dirtyWorkFactory - see startANewMission(String, String, br.eti.fml.behavior.Factory, Capsule, int, int, int)
capsule - see startANewMission(String, String, br.eti.fml.behavior.Factory, Capsule, int, int, int)
See Also:

stopAllMissions

public void stopAllMissions()
                     throws java.lang.InterruptedException
Stop all missions.

Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException - If the Thread was interrupted while waiting for every consumer die.

stopTheMission

public void stopTheMission(java.lang.String missionName)
                    throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                           UnregisteredMissionException
Stop a specific mission.

Parameters:
missionName - The mission name used when you have started a mission.
Throws:
java.lang.InterruptedException - If the Thread was interrupted while waiting for every consumer die.
UnregisteredMissionException - If the mission was not started before.

buildANewInstance

public MachineGun buildANewInstance()
Just to keep the factory contract, use getANewMachineGun(java.lang.String). This function will use the last used mission.

Specified by:
buildANewInstance in class Factory<MachineGun>
Returns:
a new instance.
See Also:
getANewMachineGun(java.lang.String)

getAMission

getANewMachineGun

public <T> MachineGun<T> getANewMachineGun(java.lang.String missionName)
                                throws UnregisteredMissionException
Produces a shiny and new machine gun.

Parameters:
missionName - the associated mission
Returns:
a new machine gun to be used immediately.
Throws:
UnregisteredMissionException - If you forget to start a mission before using this.
